title: 107_hr4209
content: The "Promoting Self-Reliance for the World's Poorest Act of 2002" reauthorizes microenterprise assistance programs with increased funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. The "Promoting Self-Reliance for the World's Poorest Act of 2002" amends Section 131(b) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to require that programs or services support clients who are initially very poor or living on less than $1 per day. The "Promoting Self-Reliance for the World's Poorest Act of 2002" amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to require programs to support clients living in poverty. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development will develop methods to measure poverty levels of clients in microenterprise programs. Cost-efficient sampling methods will be used to identify individuals in the bottom 50 percent of poverty. The Administrator will develop cost-efficient sampling methods to identify individuals living in poverty, specifically those in the bottom 50 percent below the official poverty line or living on less than $1 per day. The Administrator will implement interim and final poverty measurement methods for sustainable poverty-focused programs by specific deadlines. Programs will be distributed equitably among countries and regions. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development will implement poverty measurement methods for programs by specific deadlines. Grant assistance to programs must qualify as targeted assistance to the very poor if at least 50 percent of clients are among the very poor. A report with interim poverty measurement methods and analysis results must be submitted to Congress by July 1, 2004. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development will implement final poverty measurement methods by September 30, 2004, for sustainable poverty-focused programs.
